sn7.18:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.
sn7.18:1.2: Then several youths, students of one of the Bhāradvāja brahmins, approached a forest grove while collecting firewood. They saw the Buddha sitting down cross-legged at the root of a certain sal tree, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in front of him. Seeing this, they went up to Bhāradvāja and said to him,
sn7.18:1.4: In such and such a forest grove the ascetic Gotama is sitting down cross-legged, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in front of him.”
sn7.18:1.5: Then Bhāradvāja together with those students went to that forest grove
sn7.18:1.6: where he saw the Buddha sitting down cross-legged, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in front of him.
sn7.18:1.7: He went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:
sn7.18:2.1: “Deep in the jungle so full of terrors,
sn7.18:2.2: you’ve plunged into the empty, desolate wilderness.
sn7.18:3.1: Where there is no song or music,
sn7.18:3.2: a lonely sage resorts to the wilderness.
sn7.18:3.3: This strikes me as an amazing thing,
sn7.18:3.4: that you dwell so joyfully alone in the jungle.
sn7.18:4.1: I suppose you wish to be reborn in the company
sn7.18:4.2: of the supreme sovereign <j>of the heaven of the Three and Thirty.
sn7.18:4.3: Is that why you resort to the desolate wilderness,
sn7.18:4.4: to practice fervor for attaining Brahmā?”
sn7.18:5.1: “Any wishes and hopes that are always attached
sn7.18:5.2: to the many and various realms—
sn7.18:5.3: the yearnings sprung from the root of unknowing—
sn7.18:5.4: I’ve eliminated them all down to the root.
sn7.18:6.2: amongst all things, my vision is clear.
sn7.18:6.3: I’ve attained the state of grace, <j>the supreme awakening;
sn7.18:6.4: I meditate alone, brahmin, and self-assured.”
sn7.18:7.1: When he had spoken, Bhāradvāja said to the Buddha,
sn7.18:7.3: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
